item.title: Installing the Operator
item.description: Installing the Operator In this chapter you will prepare your Cluster for the installation of AI Manager Prepare your PC or Mac to run commands against your cluster Create the basic resources (Namespace) Create the IBM Operator Catalog Install the CP4WAIOPS Operator

item.title: Preparing to run commands
item.description: Preparing to run commands The official documentation can be found here. Befor continuing, you have to connect to your OpenShift Cluster. Open your Openshift Web Console Select Copy Login Command Copy the oc login .. string Open your terminal Paste the oc login .. command from above Clone the GitHub Repository into your directory of choice git clone https://github.com/niklaushirt/cp4waiops-deployer.git Go to the deployer directory cd cp4waiops-deployer Now you’re good to start with the installation.

item.title: Preparing Installation
item.description: Preparing Installation Create the namespace (project) ðŸ’¡ This creates the Namespace in which you will install AI Manager Create a namespace called cp4waiops, by running the following command: oc create namespace cp4waiops Create the OperatorGroup ðŸ’¡ This creates the OperatorGroup needed for the Operator to deploy into the cp4waiops Namespace Create the Operator group by running the following command: cat << EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1 kind: OperatorGroup metadata: name: cp4waiops-operator-group namespace: cp4waiops spec: targetNamespaces: - cp4waiops EOF Create the entitlement key pull secret ðŸ’¡ This creates the Secret with your IBM Entitlement that will allow the images to be pulled from the IBM Container Registry

item.title: Install Catalog
item.description: Installing the Catalog ðŸ’¡ This creates the CatalogSource that provides the available IBM Operators (not just CP4WAIOPS). You can go to Operators/OperatorHub in your Openshift Web Console to check out the available Operators Run the following command to create the CatalogSource. cat << EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1alpha1 kind: CatalogSource metadata: name: ibm-operator-catalog namespace: openshift-marketplace spec: displayName: ibm-operator-catalog publisher: IBM Content sourceType: grpc image: icr.io/cpopen/ibm-operator-catalog:latest EOF Update the CatalogSource to always use the current image digest by running the following commands:

item.title: Install Operator
item.description: Installing the Operator ðŸ’¡ This creates the Operator instance that will be looking for an Installation definition and start the installation if it exists (you’ll create this in one of the next steps). Run the following command: cat << EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1alpha1 kind: Subscription metadata: name: ibm-aiops-orchestrator namespace: cp4waiops spec: channel: v3.5 installPlanApproval: Automatic name: ibm-aiops-orchestrator source: ibm-operator-catalog sourceNamespace: openshift-marketplace EOF

item.title: Check Installation
item.description: Check Operator is ready Verify that the Operator is running. Either run the following: oc get csv -n cp4waiops And you should see TODO entries with Succeeded state NAME DISPLAY VERSION REPLACES PHASE ibm-aiops-orchestrator.v3.5.1 IBM Cloud Pak for Watson AIOps AI Manager 3.5.1 Succeeded ibm-automation-core.v1.3.11 IBM Automation Foundation Core 1.3.11 ibm-automation-core.v1.3.10 Succeeded ibm-automation-elastic.v1.3.10 IBM Elastic 1.3.10 ibm-automation-elastic.v1.3.9 Succeeded ibm-automation-eventprocessing.v1.3.11 IBM Automation Foundation Event Processing 1.3.11 ibm-automation-eventprocessing.v1.3.10 Succeeded ibm-automation-flink.v1.3.10 IBM Automation Foundation Flink 1.
